demographics.name: Sarah Chen
demographics.supportServices: Nutrition Consult (Pre-Tx), Speech Path Consult (Pre-Tx), PEG Tube placed

diagnosis.primary: Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCCa) of the Left Tonsil
diagnosis.symptomsAtPresentation: Persistent sore throat, feeling of lump in throat, palpable left neck node.
diagnosis.relevantHistory: Former smoker (quit 15 yrs ago), social EtOH.

treatmentPlan.modality: External Beam Radiation Therapy (EBRT) with concurrent Chemotherapy
treatmentPlan.rtRxDetails: 70 Gy / 35 fx (SIB to PTV_High), PTV_Int: 63Gy, PTV_Low: 56Gy
treatmentPlan.targetVolumeSummary: PTV_High (GTV L Tonsil + L N1 node + margin), PTV_Intermediate (High-Risk Nodal Regions), PTV_Low (Elective Nodal Regions)
treatmentPlan.detailedConcurrentChemo: Cisplatin 100 mg/m^2 IV every 3 weeks (Cycles on Day 1, 22, 43) - Managed by Dr. Lisa Green
medications: Pain Medication (e.g., Oxycodone PRN severe throat pain)
PEG tube placed pre-treatment for nutritional support

ctSimulation.setupInstructions: Supine in custom thermoplastic mask extending to shoulders, appropriate headrest, shoulders retracted down. SAD setup.
ctSimulation.referenceMarks: 3-point mask marks aligned to room lasers. Isocenter at L0.0, L+1.0, V-3.0 from CT sim reference point.
ctSimulation.scanner: e.g., Philips Big Bore CT or similar
ctSimulation.ctNotes: CT acquired for H&N IMRT planning. Fused with diagnostic PET/CT. Dental eval completed prior. Patient tolerated well. Mask fit confirmed.

dosimetry.constraints: Spinal Cord Max < 45 Gy; Brainstem Max < 54 Gy; Parotid Mean < 26 Gy

fractions.setupNotes: CBCT daily, good match. Mask fit well.
fractions.sideEffects: Pre-medicated for chemo. No acute RT side effects.

imagingAndReports.summary: Asymmetric soft tissue fullness L tonsillar fossa. Enlarged L Level II nodes.

reportDetails.findings: Asymmetric soft tissue fullness and enhancement noted in the left tonsillar fossa. Several enlarged lymph nodes identified in the left Level II region, the largest measuring 1.8 cm in short axis dimension with some central low density concerning for necrosis. Right neck appears unremarkable.
reportDetails.impression: Findings suspicious for left oropharyngeal primary malignancy with associated cervical lymphadenopathy. PET/CT recommended for further evaluation and staging.

imagingAndReports.summary: Hypermetabolic L tonsillar mass (SUV 12.1) and L Level II nodes (SUV 9.5). No distant mets.

reportDetails.findings: Intense FDG uptake (SUVmax 12.1) corresponding to the soft tissue mass in the left tonsillar fossa/oropharynx. Intense uptake (SUVmax 9.5) in the enlarged left Level II cervical lymph nodes. No other suspicious FDG-avid foci identified in the head, neck, chest, abdomen, or pelvis.
reportDetails.impression: Hypermetabolic primary oropharyngeal malignancy with ipsilateral cervical nodal metastases. No evidence of distant metastatic disease.

reportDetails.diagnosis: SQUAMOUS CELL CARCINOMA, INVASIVE, HPV-RELATED (p16 POSITIVE).
reportDetails.microscopicDescription: Sections show fragments of squamous mucosa with underlying infiltration by nests and islands of atypical squamous cells with keratinization. Mitotic figures are present. Immunohistochemical stain for p16 shows strong, diffuse nuclear and cytoplasmic positivity in the tumor cells.
reportDetails.comment: The histologic features and p16 positivity are consistent with HPV-related invasive squamous cell carcinoma.

imagingAndReports.summary: Contrast-enhanced CT for IMRT planning, fused with PET/CT.

reportDetails.procedure: CT simulation for Head and Neck IMRT.
reportDetails.setup: Patient positioned supine in custom thermoplastic mask extending to shoulders, with appropriate headrest. Shoulders retracted down.
reportDetails.scanParams: Contrast-enhanced CT scan acquired from vertex through carina with 2.5 mm slice thickness.
reportDetails.fusion: Diagnostic PET/CT (02/01/2025) fused with simulation CT dataset for target volume delineation. Dental evaluation previously completed.
reportDetails.notes: Patient tolerated procedure well. Mask fit confirmed. Setup marks placed on mask. Data sent for IMRT planning.

progressNotes.author: Dr. Emily White (ENT)
progressNotes.summary: Pt with sore throat, neck lump. Exam shows L tonsil mass, +L neck node. Biopsy performed -> SCCa, HPV+. PET/CT ordered. Referrals to Rad Onc/Med Onc.

progressNotes.author: Dr. James Miller (Rad Onc)
progressNotes.summary: Reviewed case T2N1M0 HPV+ SCCa L tonsil. Discussed definitive chemoradiation (IMRT 70Gy/35fx SIB + concurrent Cisplatin). Plan reviewed w/ Med Onc. Explained extensive side effects (mucositis, dermatitis, xerostomia, fatigue, chemo SEs). PEG tube strongly recommended. Pt agrees to plan. CT sim scheduled.

progressNotes.author: Nutrition/Speech Path
progressNotes.summary: PEG tube placed per recommendations. Swallowing exercises initiated. Nutritional plan discussed.

progressNotes.author: Dr. Lisa Green (Med Onc)
progressNotes.summary: Patient receives Cycle 1 Cisplatin 100mg/m2. Pre-hydration given. Labs reviewed (adequate renal fxn/electrolytes). Anti-emetics provided. Toxicity discussed.

progressNotes.author: Dr. James Miller (Rad Onc)
progressNotes.summary: Pt c/o moderate throat pain (Grade 2 mucositis), using Magic Mouthwash + PRN pain meds. Skin Grade 1 erythema. Tolerating PEG feeds. Labs show low Mg, supplement started. Continue RT/chemo. Supportive care emphasized.

patientEducation.sideEffectsReviewed: Mucositis (mouth/throat sores), dermatitis (skin reaction), xerostomia (dry mouth), dysphagia (difficulty swallowing), taste changes, fatigue, nausea/vomiting (from chemo), low blood counts (from chemo), potential need for PEG tube, long-term risk of dental issues/neck fibrosis/hypothyroidism.
patientEducation.safetyConsiderations: Oral hygiene protocol (soft brush, fluoride), skin care (moisturizers, avoid irritants), PEG tube care, hydration/nutrition goals, signs/symptoms to report urgently (fever, severe pain, inability to swallow).
patientEducation.patientResponsibilities: Attend daily RT/weekly chemo, manage PEG feeds if needed, adhere to oral/skin care, maintain nutrition/hydration, attend weekly OTVs/labs.
patientEducation.medicationCompliance: Importance of anti-nausea meds, pain meds as needed, use of Magic Mouthwash/other oral agents, any electrolyte supplements (e.g., Magnesium).
